clusters.title: Greenlanders protest as Trump makes latest tariff threats against NATO allies

items.title: Greenlanders protest as Trump makes latest tariff threats against NATO allies
items.standfirst: Greenlanders protested President Trump's proposed U.S. acquisition of the Arctic island. Meanwhile, Mr. Trump threatened tariffs against European allies who don't support his plan. CBS News' Olivia Gazis has more.
items.content: Greenlanders protested President Trump's proposed U.S. acquisition of the Arctic island. Meanwhile, Mr. Trump threatened tariffs against European allies who don't support his plan. CBS News' Olivia Gazis has more.

items.title: Minister defends UK’s decision not to hit back at Trump tariffs threat, saying ‘aim is to de-escalate’ – as it happened
items.standfirst: Development minister defends Keir Starmer playing down the prospect of retaliatory tariffs But, Starmer says, the future of Greenland is for a matter for Denmark and Greenland to decide on their own.There is a principle here that cannot be set aside, because it goes to the heart of how stable and trusted international cooperation works.And so any decision about the future status of Greenland belongs to the people of Greenland and the Kingdom of Denmark alone. That right is fundamental and we support it.On Greenland, the right way to approach an issue of this seriousness is through calm discussion between allies.And let’s be clear, the security of Greenland matters, and it will matter more as climate change reshapes the Arctic, as sea routes open and strategic competition intensifies. Continue reading...
items.content: Development minister defends Keir Starmer playing down the prospect of retaliatory tariffs But, Starmer says, the future of Greenland is for a matter for Denmark and Greenland to decide on their own.There is a principle here that cannot be set aside, because it goes to the heart of how stable and trusted international cooperation works.And so any decision about the future status of Greenland belongs to the people of Greenland and the Kingdom of Denmark alone. That right is fundamental and we support it.On Greenland, the right way to approach an issue of this seriousness is through calm discussion between allies.And let’s be clear, the security of Greenland matters, and it will matter more as climate change reshapes the Arctic, as sea routes open and strategic competition intensifies. Continue reading...

items.title: Donald Trump links Greenland threats to Nobel snub as EU trade war looms
items.standfirst: US president tells Norwegian PM he no longer feels obliged to think ‘purely of peace’ as relations with Europe plunge into chaosDonald Trump has linked his repeated threats to seize control of Greenland to his failure to win the Nobel peace prize, as transatlantic tensions over the Arctic island escalated further and threatened to rekindle a trade war with the EU.In an extraordinary text message sent on Sunday to the Norwegian prime minister, Jonas Gahr Støre, the US president wrote that after being snubbed for the prize, he no longer felt the need to think “purely of peace”. Continue reading...
items.content: US president tells Norwegian PM he no longer feels obliged to think ‘purely of peace’ as relations with Europe plunge into chaosDonald Trump has linked his repeated threats to seize control of Greenland to his failure to win the Nobel peace prize, as transatlantic tensions over the Arctic island escalated further and threatened to rekindle a trade war with the EU.In an extraordinary text message sent on Sunday to the Norwegian prime minister, Jonas Gahr Støre, the US president wrote that after being snubbed for the prize, he no longer felt the need to think “purely of peace”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump links Greenland ambitions to Nobel Peace Prize snub
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump linked his aggressive stance on Greenland to last year’s decision not to award him the Nobel Peace Prize, telling Norway’s prime minister that he no longer felt “an obligation to think purely of Peace,” two European officials said Monday. Trump's message to Jonas Gahr Støre appears to ratchet up a standoff between Washington and its closest allies over his threats to take over Greenland, a self-governing territory of NATO member Denmark. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani brings you this analysis.
items.content: US President Donald Trump linked his aggressive stance on Greenland to last year’s decision not to award him the Nobel Peace Prize, telling Norway’s prime minister that he no longer felt “an obligation to think purely of Peace,” two European officials said Monday. Trump's message to Jonas Gahr Støre appears to ratchet up a standoff between Washington and its closest allies over his threats to take over Greenland, a self-governing territory of NATO member Denmark. FRANCE 24's Kethevane Gorjestani brings you this analysis.

items.title: UK PM Starmer says trade war in no one’s interest after Trump's tariff threats
items.standfirst: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Monday that US President Donald Trump’s threat of tariffs against allies over Greenland is “completely wrong” and a trade war is in no one’s interest. Trump said Saturday that he would charge a 10% import tax starting in February on goods from eight European nations, including the UK, because of their opposition to American control of Greenland, setting up a potentially dangerous test of US partnerships in Europe. Greenland is a semiautonomous territory of NATO ally Denmark.
items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer said Monday that US President Donald Trump’s threat of tariffs against allies over Greenland is “completely wrong” and a trade war is in no one’s interest. Trump said Saturday that he would charge a 10% import tax starting in February on goods from eight European nations, including the UK, because of their opposition to American control of Greenland, setting up a potentially dangerous test of US partnerships in Europe. Greenland is a semiautonomous territory of NATO ally Denmark.

items.title: 'Most challenging situation’ for transatlantic relations as Trump threatens EU with tariffs
items.standfirst: EU member states on Monday are exploring countermeasures in response to US President Donald Trump's tariff threats over Greenland, which he has expressed interest in acquiring despite opposition from Denmark and the EU. “This is not only about trade; it is putting enormous, unexpected stress on the transatlantic relationship,” said Carsten Brzeski, Global Head of Macro for ING Research, adding that it is likely the most challenging situation for transatlantic relations since the end of World War II. "There are no winners in trade wars", he said.
items.content: EU member states on Monday are exploring countermeasures in response to US President Donald Trump's tariff threats over Greenland, which he has expressed interest in acquiring despite opposition from Denmark and the EU. “This is not only about trade; it is putting enormous, unexpected stress on the transatlantic relationship,” said Carsten Brzeski, Global Head of Macro for ING Research, adding that it is likely the most challenging situation for transatlantic relations since the end of World War II. "There are no winners in trade wars", he said.

items.title: Trump hits Denmark and 7 other U.S. allies with tariffs, escalating standoff over Greenland
items.standfirst: President Trump announced Saturday he would impose a 10% tariff starting Feb. 1 on all goods from Denmark and seven other European countries until a deal is in place allowing the U.S. to buy Greenland. Trump says the tariff will increase to 25% on June 1 for the eight NATO allies if no deal is reached. NBC News’ Melanie Zanona reports.
items.content: President Trump announced Saturday he would impose a 10% tariff starting Feb. 1 on all goods from Denmark and seven other European countries until a deal is in place allowing the U.S. to buy Greenland. Trump says the tariff will increase to 25% on June 1 for the eight NATO allies if no deal is reached. NBC News’ Melanie Zanona reports.

items.title: Valentino, fashion designer to the jet set, dies aged 93 in Rome
items.standfirst: By JENNY BARCHFIELD and COLLEEN BARRY, Associated Press ROME — Valentino Garavani, the jet-set Italian designer whose high-glamour gowns — often in his trademark shade of “Valentino red” — were fashion show staples for nearly half a century, has died at home in Rome, his foundation announced…
items.content: By JENNY BARCHFIELD and COLLEEN BARRY, Associated Press ROME — Valentino Garavani, the jet-set Italian designer whose high-glamour gowns — often in his trademark shade of “Valentino red” — were fashion show staples for nearly half a century, has died at home in Rome, his foundation announced…

items.title: Italian fashion designer Valentino dies aged 93
items.standfirst: His eponymous label is renowned for its opulent, elegant take on women’s fashion and has a legion of famous fansValentino Garavani, the designer central to pioneering Italian glamour with his eponymous fashion house, has died aged 93.“Valentino Garavani passed away today at his Roman residence, surrounded by his loved ones,” his foundation said on Instagram on Monday. “Valentino Garavani was not only a constant guide and inspiration for all of us, but a true source of light, creativity and vision,” it added. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Celebrated Italian fashion designer Valentino dies aged 93
items.standfirst: Italian haute couture designer Valentino Garavani died at his home in Rome, his foundation said Monday. He was 93. Universally known by his first name, Valentino was adored by generations of royals, first ladies and movie stars, from Jackie Kennedy Onassis to Julia Roberts and Queen Rania of Jordan.
items.content: Italian haute couture designer Valentino Garavani died at his home in Rome, his foundation said Monday. He was 93. Universally known by his first name, Valentino was adored by generations of royals, first ladies and movie stars, from Jackie Kennedy Onassis to Julia Roberts and Queen Rania of Jordan.

items.title: Valentino, founder of Italian luxury empire, dies at the age of 93
items.standfirst: Italian fashion designer Valentino Garavani has passed away at the age of 93, his foundation announced. "Valentino Garavani passed away today at his Roman residence, surrounded by his loved ones," the foundation said on Instagram. NBC News' Claudio Lavanga reports on the loss of one of the world's most iconic fashion designers.
items.content: Italian fashion designer Valentino Garavani has passed away at the age of 93, his foundation announced. "Valentino Garavani passed away today at his Roman residence, surrounded by his loved ones," the foundation said on Instagram. NBC News' Claudio Lavanga reports on the loss of one of the world's most iconic fashion designers.

clusters.title: High-speed train derailment kills at least 40 in Spain, police say
clusters.neutral_headline: High-speed train crash in Spain kills at least 39

items.title: High-speed train derailment kills at least 40 in Spain, police say
items.standfirst: Spanish police said Monday that at least 40 people died and 159 were injured in a high-speed train collision in southern Spain.
items.content: Spanish police said Monday that at least 40 people died and 159 were injured in a high-speed train collision in southern Spain.

items.title: Dozens injured by train crash in southern Spain still in hospital
items.standfirst: The Spanish government vowed Monday to conduct a full investigation into the causes of a high-speed train collision that killed at least 39 people, with officials warning the death toll could rise as rescuers worked among the wreckage. FRANCE 24's Sarah Morris reported that 48 injured are still in hospital and that the government has announced three days of national mourning for the tragedy.
items.content: The Spanish government vowed Monday to conduct a full investigation into the causes of a high-speed train collision that killed at least 39 people, with officials warning the death toll could rise as rescuers worked among the wreckage. FRANCE 24's Sarah Morris reported that 48 injured are still in hospital and that the government has announced three days of national mourning for the tragedy.

items.title: Spain train crash: What we know about the fatal derailment so far
items.standfirst: At least 40 people have been killed and 170 others injured after two high-speed trains derailed in southern Spain on Sunday.
items.content: At least 40 people have been killed and 170 others injured after two high-speed trains derailed in southern Spain on Sunday.

items.title: High-speed train crash in Spain kills at least 39
items.standfirst: More than 400 passengers were on board the trains that derailed near the city of Córdoba, in Spain's worst rail crash in more than a decade.
items.content: More than 400 passengers were on board the trains that derailed near the city of Córdoba, in Spain's worst rail crash in more than a decade.

items.title: At least 39 dead, dozens injured in high-speed train collision in Spain
items.standfirst: At least 39 people were killed, and dozens were injured when part of a high-speed train derailed and collided with an oncoming train on an opposite track in southern Spain.
items.content: At least 39 people were killed, and dozens were injured when part of a high-speed train derailed and collided with an oncoming train on an opposite track in southern Spain.

items.title: At least 39 dead in Spain train collision as rescuers search for more bodies
items.standfirst: Spanish police said Monday that at least 39 people died in the a high-speed train collision Sunday in southern Spain and rescue efforts were continuing.
items.content: Spanish police said Monday that at least 39 people died in the a high-speed train collision Sunday in southern Spain and rescue efforts were continuing.(Image credit: Francisco J. Olmo)

items.title: At least 40 dead, dozens injured after high-speed trains collide in Spain
items.standfirst: A high-speed train derailed in southern Spain on Sunday, jumping onto the track in the opposite direction and hitting an oncoming train in an accident that authorities estimate left more than 20 people dead and dozens injured.
items.content: A high-speed train derailed in southern Spain on Sunday, jumping onto the track in the opposite direction and hitting an oncoming train in an accident that authorities estimate left more than 20 people dead and dozens injured.

clusters.title: Judge rules on tactics used by ICE against peaceful protesters
clusters.neutral_headline: Noem backtracks on ICE pepper spray denial amid tension in Minneapolis

items.title: Judge rules on tactics used by ICE against peaceful protesters
items.standfirst: A judge ruled Friday that federal agents are not allowed to use pepper spray against peaceful protesters or arrest them without probable cause. The Trump administration has not yet responded. Meanwhile, the Justice Department launched an investigation into Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, officials say. CBS News immigration reporter Camilo Montoya-Galvez has more.
items.content: A judge ruled Friday that federal agents are not allowed to use pepper spray against peaceful protesters or arrest them without probable cause. The Trump administration has not yet responded. Meanwhile, the Justice Department launched an investigation into Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, officials say. CBS News immigration reporter Camilo Montoya-Galvez has more.

items.title: DOJ says it will investigate, press charges after activists disrupt church where Minnesota ICE official is a pastor

items.content: U.S. officials tell CBS News that the Justice Department has opened an investigation into Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz and Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey. CBS News legal contributor Jessica Levinson has more.

items.title: Noem backtracks on ICE pepper spray denial amid tension in Minneapolis
items.standfirst: US justice department announced it is investigating protesters in Minnesota who disrupted church servicesKristi Noem first denied that federal agents were using chemical agents against protesters, then after being shown video footage turned to blaming the protesters themselves, as tensions continued to run high amid the Trump administration’s surge of federal officers into Minneapolis.The head of homeland security, who has acted as spearhead for the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operation in the city – known as “Operation Metro Surge” – told the CBS show Face the Nation on Sunday that her department had not used pepper spray against crowds. Continue reading...
items.content: US justice department announced it is investigating protesters in Minnesota who disrupted church servicesKristi Noem first denied that federal agents were using chemical agents against protesters, then after being shown video footage turned to blaming the protesters themselves, as tensions continued to run high amid the Trump administration’s surge of federal officers into Minneapolis.The head of homeland security, who has acted as spearhead for the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) operation in the city – known as “Operation Metro Surge” – told the CBS show Face the Nation on Sunday that her department had not used pepper spray against crowds. Continue reading...

items.title: WATCH: Bessent says it would be 'very unwise' for Europe to retaliate over Trump threats on Greenland
items.standfirst: The EU is considering countermeasures, including new tariffs and using its Anti-Coercion Instrument.
items.content: The EU is considering countermeasures, including new tariffs and using its Anti-Coercion Instrument.

items.title: A look at the EU's 'Anti-Coercion Instrument' amid Greenland dispute with US
items.standfirst: Trump on Saturday threatened to impose more tariffs on eight European nations until the US is allowed to buy Greenland, citing US national security concerns. EU governments are drawing up retaliatory measures, including possibly ​hitting the US with 93 billion euros' worth of tariffs or the so far unused "Anti-Coercion Instrument", which permits investment ‍restrictions and curbs the export of services such as those provided by US digital giants.
items.content: Trump on Saturday threatened to impose more tariffs on eight European nations until the US is allowed to buy Greenland, citing US national security concerns. EU governments are drawing up retaliatory measures, including possibly ​hitting the US with 93 billion euros' worth of tariffs or the so far unused "Anti-Coercion Instrument", which permits investment ‍restrictions and curbs the export of services such as those provided by US digital giants.

Speaking to Bloomberg TV’s Haslinda Amin in Davos, she said AI could work with doctors to provide better healthcare for patients. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Lecornu: 'Bitter' to have to use special law for budget
clusters.neutral_headline: Lecornu: 'Bitter' to have to use special law for budget

items.title: Lecornu: 'Bitter' to have to use special law for budget
items.standfirst: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu addressed the public on Monday, confirming that he will be using special constitutional powers to pass the spending budget for 2026 without a parliamentary vote...
items.content: French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu addressed the public on Monday, confirming that he will be using special constitutional powers to pass the spending budget for 2026 without a parliamentary vote...

items.title: French PM Lecornu will use special power to force through budget with ‘regret’
items.standfirst: French ​Prime ⁠Minister Sébastien Lecornu confirmed on Monday that he will invoke a special ​constitutional power, Article 49.3, to force a budget ‍for 2026 ​through parliament without a vote. The decision, he said, was made with "regret" after budget negotiations came to an impasse. The use of Article 49.3 can trigger a no-confidence vote, which can topple the government.
items.content: French ​Prime ⁠Minister Sébastien Lecornu confirmed on Monday that he will invoke a special ​constitutional power, Article 49.3, to force a budget ‍for 2026 ​through parliament without a vote. The decision, he said, was made with "regret" after budget negotiations came to an impasse. The use of Article 49.3 can trigger a no-confidence vote, which can topple the government.

items.title: French PM Lecornu inches closer to passing budget bill without vote
items.standfirst: France’s government is set to meet Monday to discuss a highly controversial budget bill that has left Prime Minister Sebastian Lecornu and political parties at an impasse. Lecornu is moving closer to pushing the bill through parliament without a vote, while simultaneously seeking a way to avoid being toppled by parliament over the measure. FRANCE 24's Marc Perelman explains.
items.content: France’s government is set to meet Monday to discuss a highly controversial budget bill that has left Prime Minister Sebastian Lecornu and political parties at an impasse. Lecornu is moving closer to pushing the bill through parliament without a vote, while simultaneously seeking a way to avoid being toppled by parliament over the measure. FRANCE 24's Marc Perelman explains.
